title-group.article-title: Influence of the morphology of thermoplastic elastomers on the properties of bitumen composites

article-meta.aff: 1ICECHIM Bucharest, Independence Street, No. 202, code 060021, Bucharest, Romania.
2SC Rompetrol Rafinare SA, District Road 226, Km. 23, Constanta, Romania.
3Faculty of Material Science and Applied Chemistry, University Politehnica of Bucharest, Clea Victoriei, No. 149, Bucharest, Romania.
4Academy Inst. of Chemistry and Physics, “I.C.Murgulescu”, Independence Street, no 202, code 060021, Bucharest, Romania.

author-notes.corresp: Doina Dimonie, ICECHIM Bucharest, Independence Street, No. 202, code 060021, Bucharest, Romania Emails: ddimonie@icf.ro; ddimonie@rdslink.ro

abstract.p: Bitumen properties may be successfully modified if the polymeric modifiers have the ability to control the elastic and plastic properties within wide temperature ranges of −30/−40°C to +45/+60°C. The article presents a study on the ability of two thermoplastic elastomers, thermoplastic block co-polymer styrene–styrene butadiene (SBS) and the co-polymer ethylene–vinyl acetate (EVA), to be used in obtaining polymer bitumen composites with controlled properties.

The elastic and plastic properties of the bitumen composites can be more easily controlled if these composites are modified with SBS. This thermoplastic elastomer is characterized by an optimum ratio between soft domains of amorphous polybutadiene and rigid ones of those represented by the thermoplastic blocks of polystyrene.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The application of the bitumen composites usually requires elastic and plastic properties within wide temperature limits, ranging from −30/−40°C and up to +45/+60°C. Such a wide interval of properties would be possible if these composites are obtained by physical modification of the bitumen with polymers. 1
–38

In order to modify the bitumen, several polymers have been used over the years: thermoplastic, 11
–18 elastomers, 19,25 thermoplastic and elastomer mixtures, 21
–29 thermoplastic elastomers. 14,26 ,34 The bitumen–polymer systems behave as composites, in which the polymer has a strengthening function. 35 The morphology of the bitumen–polymer composites can be a homogenous dispersion or a bi-continuous network. 36–38

While the thermoplastic polymers improve the plastic properties on positive temperature intervals, the elastomers provide the elastic properties within the range of negative temperatures. In order to improve the plastic and elastic properties, mixtures of elastomers and thermoplastic polymers or, most frequently, thermoplastic elastomers are used. In contrast, with elastomers, the thermoplastic elastomers have an advantage: they are able to provide a wide range of properties because the elastic deformation is controlled by a system of physical crosslinks and not a chemical one as in elastomers. The physical crosslinks are represented by low mobility chain segments such as: crystalline zones, rigid blocks etc. The low mobility of the chain segments may also be the result of hydrogen bonds or dipole. The stability in a mechanic field and the capacity to reverse the deformation depends on the density of crosslinks. A too high crosslink density gives a very good stability in a mechanical field, but reduces elasticity under the mechanic strain. 37,41
–46

The article presents a study about the ability of two thermoplastic elastomers, thermoplastic block co-polymer styrene–styrene butadiene (SBS) and the co-polymer ethylene–vinyl acetate (EVA), used to obtain polymeric bitumen composites with controlled properties.

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p: The polymers were dispersed into the bituminous matrix in a steel autoclave with stirring, by 200–2500 rpm, at 160–180°C, and 2–12 h.

list-item.p: Ethylene–vinyl acetate copolymers (EVA1), vinyl acetate content 33% wt, MFI = 1.8 g/10 min, 1% secant modulus 6 MPa, elongation at break 900%;
Ethylene–vinyl acetate copolymer (EVA2), vinyl acetate content 33% wt, MFI = 45 g/10 min, melting point 57°C;

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p:
The bitumen–polymer composites were characterized by measuring the following properties before and after the accelerating thermo-oxidative aging test (T = 163°C, t = 50 min, RTFOT oven):
Penetration at 25°C: consistency of the bituminous material, expressed as the distance in tenths of a millimeter that a standard needle vertically penetrates a sample of the material under known conditions of loading, time and temperature; determination precision by 1–5 tenths of a millimeter.
Ring and ball softening point: two horizontal disks of bitumen, cast in shouldered brass rings, are heated at a controlled rate in a liquid bath while each supports a steel ball. The softening point is reported as the mean of the temperatures at which the two disks soften enough to allow each ball enveloped in bitumen to fall a distance of 25 mm;
Ductility, measured with a ductilometer, represents the distance in cm to which the composite will elongate before breaking when a standard briquette specimen of the material is pulled apart at a specified speed and a specified temperature;
Elastic recovery, in a ductilometer at the test temperature (typically 25°C), is measured by the percentage to which the composite will recover its original length after it has been elongated to a specific distance at a specific rate of speed and then cut in half.
Homogeneity, measured with a fluorescent light microscope, particle size 5µ, min 80%. The thermoplastic elastomers were characterized by the following methods:
Thermogravimetric analysisusing a Paulik–Erdey Derivatograph, MOM-Budapest, 50 mg of sample, heating rate 10°C/min, in air by 30 ml/min. By thermogravimetric curves (TG) and thermogravimetric derivative (DTG) examination in the decomposition range (from room temperature until 750°C), the thermo-oxidative behaviour was determined.
Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) – Perkin Elmer Instruments Pyris Diamond calorimeter, calibrated with pure indium (Hm = 28.4 J/g; Tm = 156.68°C), in nitrogen, 5 mg of sample was sealed in aluminium caster, was heated from −160°C to 200°C, with 10°C/min.
X-ray diffraction – The variation, of the radial diffraction intensity dependence by the diffraction angle (2 theta) was recorded at room temperature, The range 2–28° (2 teta) was explored, with a step size by 0.03° (2 theta), scanning rate = 8 s/step with an identical setting of the diffractometer and using a filter with λ = 1.7921 Å. For calculating the interbasal spacing (d), Bragg’s law, according to which d = nλ/2 sinθ, was used.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The properties of the bitumen composites obtained by modification with 5% EVA having an MFI = 1.8 g/10 min, with EVA having an MFI = 45 g/10 min, and with linear SBS are presented in Table 1. The analysis of the results presented in this table shows big differences in the properties of the bitumen–polymer composite depending on the utilized modifier. The differences are related to the plastic properties (ring and ball softening point, and penetration), the elastic properties (elastic recovery) and to the morphology.

caption.p: The properties of bitumen composites obtained by modifying with 5 % EVA and 5% SBS

sec.p: At the same dispersing time (approx. 25 hours), the penetration of the SBS composite has values comparable to the values of those with EVA having an MFI = 1.8 g/10 min. However, the ring and ball softening point of this composite is higher by 27% than those with EVA having an MFI = 1.8 g/10 min and 47% higher than the composite in which EVA has an MFI = 45 g/10 min.

Elastic recovery of the SBS modified bitumen is 78% higher than the composite that contains EVA with MFI by 1.8 g/10 min, and 60% higher than the composite in which EVA has +MFI = 45 g/10 min. The elastic recovery of the SBS composite remains very high even after the accelerated thermo-oxidation aging test at a temperature of 163°C (RTFOT test) (80% compared to 7%, which is the value for the EVA composite). The higher elastic properties of the SBS bitumen composite are also underlined by the values of the Fraass breaking point, which are lower when the composite is modified by EVA (−13°C compared to −11°C).

In the case of an EVA modified composite the properties also depend on the polymer molecular weight. Even if the type with a small molecular weight have slightly better elastic qualities, their plastic properties are not yet comparable with the values of the SBS modified composite. The composites that contain EVA having an MFI = 45 g/10 min have a low softening point and a high penetration.

The morphology of the studied composites varies significantly with the dispersion time (Figure 3). In the case of SBS, the polymer is finely dispersed in time until it forms a uniform network in the bitumen matrix.

The explanations related to the properties of bitumen composites by the thermoplastic elastomer type also depend on their morphological structure. The elastic properties and the different values of temperature range within which such properties are operating, more convenient in the case of SBS, are due to the fact that this polymer is amorphous within a large range of temperature, from around −90°C and up to 250°C (Figures 1 and 2), while EVA is a semi-crystalline polymer within the range of −42.15°C 53 to around 50°C, when its crystals are melting (Figures 4 and 5). SBS has an order 2 transition around 75°C, and EVA has a crystalline content of approximately 12% when MFI is 1.8 g/10 min and of approximately 7% when MFI is 45 g/10 min (Table 2, Figure 6).

caption.p: The glass transition of SBS copolymer with MFI = 1.8 g/10 min.
The DSC of SBS with MFI = 1.8 g/10 min.
Modified bitumen morphology dependence by the thermoplastic elastomer type.
The DSC of EVA with MFI = 1.8 g/10 min.
The DSC curve of EVA with MFI = 45 g/10 min.
The X-Ray diffractograms of EVA with MFI = 1.8 g/10 min. and MFI = 45 g/10 min.

sec.p: The lower values of the Fraass breaking point of the composites which contain SBS are due to a higher capacity of SBS to support elastic deformations at negative temperatures.

The molecular weight dependence of the bitumen composites properties containing EVA is due to the different morphologies of the two studied co-polymers, depending on the molecular weight of each of them.

For the same acetate group content, the difference in the morphology is given not only by the proportion of crystalline content but also by the crystal sizes, which are larger in the copolymer with an MFI = 1.8 g/10 min (91 Å and 58 Å) and smaller when MFI = 45 g/10 min (36 Å and 34 Å) (Table 1). The behaviour in a mechanic field is worse for the bitumen composite which contains large crystals, because cracking starts between these crystals. 53 Once the cracking is formed, the material integrity will be inevitably lost.

caption.p: The crystalline content and crystal size of EVA with different molecular weight

fn.p:
where ΔHf is the– analyzed sample melting enthalpy (J/g) and ΔHf
100% the 100% crystalline polyethylene melting enthalpy (J/g).
bReported to the whole macromolecular chain.

sec.p: The different values of the softening point and of the penetration of the studied bitumen composites are related to the different hard domains (physical crosslinks) content of the two modifiers.

If SBS is formed by hard thermoplastic block of polystyrene (physical crosslinks) and soft elastomer represented by an amorphous matrix of polybutadiene (Figure 7), EVA contains as hard domains polyethylene crystals (physical crosslinks), distributed in soft domains with amorphous morphology formed by the chain segment with the vinyl acetate groups or those of non-crystallized branched polyethylene (Figure 8). 48,49

caption.p: Styrene – butadiene – styrene block copolymer chemical formula (a) and schematic representation of its morphology (b) 50 .
Ethylene – vinyl acetate copolymer chemical formula and crystalline amorphous supramolecular micro-structure (schematic representation) 52 .

sec.p: The higher values of the softening point of the composite containing SBS in contrast with those that characterize the EVA composite are due to the higher content of hard domains of the SBS (30% bond styrene), in comparison with EVA (12% crystalline phase for the type in which MFI = 1.8 g/10 min and 7% for in case in which MFI = 45 g/10 min).

The difference between the penetrations of the studied composites can be explained in the same manner. Taking into consideration that the bitumen penetration was high (75 1/10 mm), the resulting polymeric composite will have a low penetration when a high content of hard domains modifier (SBS) is used, and a high penetration when the modifier has a lower content of physical crosslinks (EVA).

Related to the morphology, especially of the EVA modified composite, two important observations were made: first of all, the fine dispersion of EVA in the bitumen matrix reaches a maximum after 16 h. After 25 h of homogenization, the polymer particles are much more uniformly distributed in the composites with SBS than in those that contain EVA. The change in the colour of EVA particles suggest possible physical–chemical processes which may lead to a growth in the interface tensions, at longer dispersing times (25 h).

The difference between the morphologies of the two composites can also be explained by the difference in the solubility of SBS and EVA in the malthene phase of the bitumen. The morphologies of the two composite types are in agreement and explain the highly different properties of the two composites.

An essential conclusion results from the previously stated observations: in order to better control the properties of the bitumen composites it is necessary to use a certain polymer type, which is optimum to combine the elastic and plastic properties in such a manner to ensure a good behaviour in the desired application.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The difference between the properties of certain bitumen composites obtained by modifying two thermoplastic elastomers, SBS and EVA, which have a different content of rigid (physical crosslinks) and soft blocks was analyzed. SBS is formed by a hard thermoplastic block of polystyrene (physical crosslinks) and soft elastomer represented by an amorphous matrix of polybutadiene. EVA contains hard domains of polyethylene crystals (physical crosslinks), distributed in soft domains represented by the amorphous material formed by the chain segment with the vinyl acetate groups or those of non-crystallized branched polyethylene.

The analysis on the results have shown great differences between the properties of the bitumen–polymer composite depending on the modifier used and related to the plastic properties (ring and ball softening point and penetration), elastic properties (elastic recovery) and morphology.

The values of the plastic properties of the bitumen composites are in agreement with the rigid domain content (physical crosslinks) of the polymeric modifier, and the elastic properties with the content of amorphous polymer.

The elastic properties and the different values of the temperature range in which these properties are operational, which is more convenient in the case of SBS, are a consequence of the fact that this polymer is amorphous at temperature ranges from approximately −90°C to 250°C, while EVA is a semi-crystalline polymer in the range −42.15°C to approximately 50°C, when its crystals are melting.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The studies were conducted during the contracts RELANSIN 438 and those with Darmanesti Refinery.
